edu.rit.numeric

Class BigInteger

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.numeric.BigInteger
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Streamable, Cloneable, Comparable<BigInteger>

    public class BigInteger
extends Object
implements Comparable<BigInteger>, Streamable, Cloneable
    Class BigInteger encapsulates an unsigned fixed-precision integer. A big integer's bit size is specified when it is constructed. The big integer's bit size remains the same for all subsequent operations. Bit positions in the big integer are numbered from 0 (least significant bit) to n−1 (most significant bit), where n is the bit size.

    Bit truncation and extension. When a value of fewer than n bits is stored in a big integer of n bits, the extra most significant bits of the big integer are set to zero. When a value of more than n bits is stored in a big integer of n bits, the extra most significant bits of the value are omitted.

    Comparison with java.math.BigInteger. Class edu.rit.numeric.BigInteger differs from the Java Platform class java.math.BigInteger in these ways:

    • Instances of class java.math.BigInteger are immutable; every method constructs a new instance to hold the result. Instances of class edu.rit.numeric.BigInteger are mutable; every operation stores the result in the instance on which the method was called. (This helps avoid the performance reduction from incessant constructor execution and garbage collection when a program does numerous computations on instances of class java.math.BigInteger.)

    • An instance of class java.math.BigInteger can have any number of bits, depending on the value. An instance of class edu.rit.numeric.BigInteger always has a fixed number of bits. Consequently, an arithmetic operation will overflow if the answer is too large to fit in the bit size of the big integer that will hold the result.

    • Instances of class java.math.BigInteger are signed. Instances of class edu.rit.numeric.BigInteger are unsigned.

    Hashed data structure keys. Class BigInteger provides the equals() and hashCode() methods, so a big integer can be used as a key in a hashed data structure. However, big integers are mutable. If a big integer is used as a key, make sure not to alter the big integer's value.

    Multiple threads. Note: Class BigInteger is not multiple thread safe.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  BigInteger.Bits
      Interface BigInteger.Bits specifies the interface for a group of bit positions to be extracted from a big integer.

        public static int wordSize(int bitSize)
        Returns the word size of a big integer with the given bit size. The word size is bitSize/32 rounded up to the nearest integer, except the minimum word size is 2.
        Parameters:
        bitSize - Bit size.
        Returns:
        Word size.

      • extractBits

        public BigInteger extractBits(BigInteger bigint,
                     int[] pos)
        Extract the given bits from the given big integer and assign them to this big integer. The bit at position pos[0] of bigint is assigned to bit 0 of this big integer, the bit at position pos[1] of bigint is assigned to bit 1 of this big integer, and so on. Any remaining unassigned bits of this big integer are set to 0. The bit size of this big integer must be greater than or equal to the length of the pos array. Each bit position in the pos array must be in the range 0 .. bitSize()−1.
        Parameters:
        bigint - Big integer from which to extract bits.
        pos - Array of bit positions to extract.
        Returns:
        This big integer.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if bigint is null. Thrown if pos is null.
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if bitSize() < pos.length. Thrown if any bit position in pos is out of bounds.

      • extractBits

        public BigInteger extractBits(BigInteger bigint,
                     BigInteger.Bits bits)
        Extract the given bits from the given big integer and assign them to this big integer. The bit at position bits.bit(0) of bigint is assigned to bit 0 of this big integer, the bit at position bits.bit(1) of bigint is assigned to bit 1 of this big integer, and so on. Any remaining unassigned bits of this big integer are set to 0. The bit size of this big integer must be greater than or equal to bits.size(). Each bit position in bits must be in the range 0 .. bitSize()−1.
        Parameters:
        bigint - Big integer from which to extract bits.
        bits - Object specifying bit positions to extract.
        Returns:
        This big integer.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if bigint is null. Thrown if bits is null.
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if bitSize() < bits.size(). Thrown if any bit position in bits is out of bounds.

      • popCount

        public int popCount()
        Returns this big integer's population count. The population count is the number of 1 bits in this big integer.
        Returns:
        Population count.

        public int leftmostOne()

        Returns:
        Position of the leftmost 1 bit in the range 0 .. bitSize()−1, or −1 if this big integer is zero.

      • pack

        public BigInteger pack(byte[] v)
        Pack the value obtained from the given byte array into this big integer in little-endian order. Bits 0 through 7 of this big integer are set to v[0], bits 8 through 15 of this big integer are set to v[1], and so on. If there are not enough bytes in v to fill this big integer, the unfilled most significant bits of this big integer are set to 0. If there are more bytes in v than needed to fill this big integer, the extra bytes in v are ignored.
        Parameters:
        v - Value array.
        Returns:
        This big integer.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.

      • pack

        public BigInteger pack(short[] v)
        Pack the value obtained from the given short array into this big integer in little-endian order. Bits 0 through 15 of this big integer are set to v[0], bits 15 through 31 of this big integer are set to v[1], and so on. If there are not enough shorts in v to fill this big integer, the unfilled most significant bits of this big integer are set to 0. If there are more shorts in v than needed to fill this big integer, the extra shorts in v are ignored.
        Parameters:
        v - Value array.
        Returns:
        This big integer.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.

      • pack

        public BigInteger pack(int[] v)
        Pack the value obtained from the given integer array into this big integer in little-endian order. Bits 0 through 31 of this big integer are set to v[0], bits 32 through 63 of this big integer are set to v[1], and so on. If there are not enough integers in v to fill this big integer, the unfilled most significant bits of this big integer are set to 0. If there are more integers in v than needed to fill this big integer, the extra integers in v are ignored.

        This big integer.

        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.

      • pack

        public BigInteger pack(long[] v)
        Pack the value obtained from the given long array into this big integer in little-endian order. Bits 0 through 63 of this big integer are set to v[0], bits 64 through 127 of this big integer are set to v[1], and so on. If there are not enough longs in v to fill this big integer, the unfilled most significant bits of this big integer are set to 0. If there are more longs in v than needed to fill this big integer, the extra longs in v are ignored.
        Parameters:
        v - Value array.
        Returns:
        This big integer.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.

      • packBigEndian

        public BigInteger packBigEndian(byte[] v)
        Pack the value obtained from the given byte array into this big integer in big-endian order. Let L = v.length. Bits 0 through 7 of this big integer are set to v[L-1], bits 8 through 15 of this big integer are set to v[L-2], and so on. If there are not enough bytes in v to fill this big integer, the unfilled most significant bits of this big integer are set to 0. If there are more bytes in v than needed to fill this big integer, the extra bytes in v are ignored.
        Parameters:
        v - Value array.
        Returns:
        This big integer.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.

      • unpack

        public BigInteger unpack(byte[] v)
        Unpack this big integer's value into the given byte array in little-endian order. v[0] is set to bits 0–7 of this big integer, v[1] is set to bits 8–15 of this big integer, and so on. If there are not enough bytes in this big integer's value to fill v, the unfilled portion of v is set to 0. If there are more bytes in this big integer's value than needed to fill v, the extra bytes in this big integer's value are ignored.
        Parameters:
        v - Value array.
        Returns:
        This big integer.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.

      • unpack

If there are more shorts in this big integer's value than needed to fill v, the extra shorts in this big integer's value are ignored.

        This big integer.
